title: About Camden
text:
Camden Otto is a dedicated basketball coach with years of experience mentoring youth and high school athletes across Nebraska and working with top collegiate programs. His coaching background includes serving as the Head JV Boys Basketball Coach at Lincoln Lutheran, leading youth teams with Supreme Court Basketball, and coaching at elite camps such as Michigan State and Kansas. He specializes in teaching fundamentals, building structured practice plans, and developing athletes who value discipline, teamwork, and strong character both on and off the court.
In addition to coaching, Camden brings extensive media and technology expertise, producing sports content for local and university programs using Adobe Premiere, Audition, After Effects, and other creative tools. He manages social media, designs promotional materials, and supports livestream and podcast production. With certifications in CPR, concussion safety, and heat illness prevention, along with proficiency in tools like Tourney Machine and Hootsuite, Camden blends strong coaching knowledge with modern media skills to enhance every program he contributes to.

title: Covid got scared of the Jayhawks
text:
On March 17, 2020, the NCAA canceled the men’s basketball championships due to the ongoing rise of the coronavirus. At the time, the three-time champions were hoping to make it a fourth in Lawrence.
As the 2020 college basketball season approached, analysts were setting their preseason odds for teams across the nation. Among the favorites were Michigan State, Kentucky, Duke, and Kansas. The Jayhawks entered the season with high expectations and one of the most complete rosters they’ve had since the glory days with Wilt Chamberlain.
Although Bill Self’s squad was not the clear favorite, they were hunting for greatness, defying the odds of anyone who stepped in their path. When the season kicked off on Tuesday, November 5, 2019, Kansas entered with +950 odds to win it all.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(dplyr)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(waffle)
library(gt)
library(ggalt)
library(ggplot2)
library(ggbump)

APPoll <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - AP Poll.csv")
CoachesPoll <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - Coaches Poll.csv")
ConStand <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - Conference Standings.csv")
PreOdds <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - Pre-Season Odds.csv")
TeamRat <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - Team Ratings.csv")
TeamStat <- read_csv("Project 2 Data/Project 2 Data - Team Stats.csv")

top10 <- PreOdds |> 
  filter(School %in% c( "Michigan State", "Kentucky", "Kansas", "Duke", "Memphis", "Louisville", "North Carolina", "Florida", "Villanova"))

KU <- PreOdds |> filter(School == "Kansas")
DU <- PreOdds |> filter(School == "Duke")
KNU <- PreOdds |> filter(School == "Kentucky")
MSU <- PreOdds |> filter(School == "Michigan State")

ggplot() + 
  geom_lollipop(data=top10, aes(y=School, x=Odds), horizontal = TRUE, color = "lightgrey") +
  geom_lollipop(data=KU, aes(y=School, x=Odds), horizontal = TRUE, color = "#0051ba", size = 1) +
  geom_lollipop(data=DU, aes(y=School, x=Odds), horizontal = TRUE, color = "#00539B", size = .5) +
  geom_lollipop(data=KNU, aes(y=School, x=Odds), horizontal = TRUE, color = "#0033a0", size = .5) +
  geom_lollipop(data=MSU, aes(y=School, x=Odds), horizontal = TRUE, color = "#18453B", size = .5) +
scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = c(0, 500, 1000, 1500, 2000),
    labels = c("0", "+500", "+1000", "+1500", "+2000")
) + 
   theme_minimal()  +
  labs(
    x="Odds", 
    y=" "
    ) +
    plot_annotation(
    title = "2020 Pre Season Odds",
    subtitle = "Who is in the hunt to claim March?",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)
  )









As the season progressed, one question kept coming up: which conference was the best? With dominant players on talented rosters, it was clear the answer would come from the Power Five.
On the East Coast, many would point to the ACC, home to some of the best coaches to ever walk the sidelines. Others argued the Big Ten was on the rise, bringing a mix of talent and strategy. But the most accurate way to settle the debate? The numbers. Conference ranking can be measured by Strength of Schedule (SOS) and Simple Rating System (SRS) grades, revealing which leagues truly tested their teams and who dominated their competition throughout the season.


Code
Big12S <- ConStand |> filter(Conference == "Big 12 Conference")
Big10S <- ConStand |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")
Pac12S <- ConStand |> filter(Conference == "Pac 12 Conference")
SECS <- ConStand |> filter(Conference == "Southeastern Conference")
ACCS <- ConStand |> filter(Conference == "Atlantic Coast Conference")

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=ConStand, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=Big12S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#E41A1C") +
  geom_text(data=Big12S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#E41A1C", label = "Big 12", nudge_x = 1, nudge_y = -1) +
  geom_point(data=Big10S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#0088CE") +
  geom_text(data=Big10S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#0088CE", label = "Big 10", nudge_x = 1, nudge_y = 1) +
  geom_point(data=Pac12S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#092346") +
  geom_text(data=Pac12S, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#092346", label = "Pac 12", nudge_x = 1, nudge_y = 1) +
  geom_point(data=SECS, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#FBCE28") +
  geom_text(data=SECS, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#FBCE28", label = "SEC", nudge_x = -1, nudge_y = 0) +
  geom_point(data=ACCS, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#013CA6") +
  geom_text(data=ACCS, aes(x = SOS, y = SRS), color = "#013CA6", label = "ACC", nudge_x = 1, nudge_y = -1) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="Strength of Schedule", 
    y="Simple Rating System "
    ) +
    plot_annotation(
    title = "2020 Conference Power Ranking",
    subtitle = "SOS and SRS favor the Big Ten",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)
  )









Although conference ratings give a sense of overall strength, they don’t tell the full story. To see who really stood out, we need to break it down team by team. Kansas, Michigan State, Duke, and Kentucky all separated themselves from the rest, showing not only talent but the ability to perform against tough competition.


Code
Big12Rat <- TeamRat |> filter(Conf == "Big 12")
Big10Rat <- TeamRat |> filter(Conf == "Big Ten")
Pac12Rat <- TeamRat |> filter(Conf == "Pac-12")
SECRat <- TeamRat |> filter(Conf == "SEC")
ACCRat <- TeamRat |> filter(Conf == "ACC")

KURat <- TeamRat |> filter(School == "Kansas")
KNRat <- TeamRat |> filter(School == "Kentucky")
DURat <- TeamRat |> filter(School == "Duke")
MSURat <- TeamRat |> filter(School == "Michigan State")

ggplot() +
  geom_point(data=TeamRat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "lightgrey") +
  geom_point(data=Big12Rat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "#E41A1C") +
  geom_point(data=KURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "#0051ba") +
  geom_point(data=KNRat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "#0033a0") +
  geom_point(data=DURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "#00539B") +
  geom_point(data=MSURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS), color = "#18453B") +
  geom_text(data=KURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=School), nudge_y=2, fontface = "bold", color = "#0051ba") +
  geom_text(data=KNRat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=School), nudge_y=2, size = 2.5, color = "#0033a0") +
  geom_text(data=DURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=School), nudge_y=2, size = 2.5, color = "#00539B") +
  geom_text(data=MSURat, aes(x=SOS, y=SRS, label=School), nudge_y=1.5, size = 2.5, color = "#18453B") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="Strength of Schedule", 
    y="Simple Rating System "
    ) +
    plot_annotation(
    title = "Recreate the Season That Never Finished",
    subtitle = "Kansas cuts down the nets when SRS and SOS tell the story",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)
  )









With a 28-3 record the Jayhawks didn’t just play the best teams, they beat them convincingly. With an SRS nearing 25 and their SOS just shy of 12, Kansas proved they belonged as a one seed heading into the madness.
Even though records, stats and grading systems show us a lot, do they share the full story with us? Polls play a huge role in shaping where teams land in March. Coaches and the Associated Press had their eyes on Kansas from the start, but where did they land when covid ruined it all?


Code
APLong <- APPoll |> pivot_longer(cols = c(-School, -Conference), names_to = "Week", values_to = "Rank") |> mutate(Week = as.numeric(Week))

CoachesLong <- CoachesPoll |> pivot_longer(cols = c(-School, -Conference), names_to = "Week", values_to = "Rank") |> mutate(Week = as.numeric(Week))


KUA <- APLong |> filter(School == "Kansas")
KUC <- CoachesLong |> filter(School == "Kansas")
KNA <- APLong |> filter(School == "Kentucky")
KNC <- CoachesLong |> filter(School == "Kentucky")
DUA <- APLong |> filter(School == "Duke")
DUC <- CoachesLong |> filter(School == "Duke")
MSUA <- APLong |> filter(School == "Michigan State")
MSUC <- CoachesLong |> filter(School == "Michigan State")



APChart <- ggplot() +
  geom_bump(data=APLong, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "lightgrey", size = .4) +
  geom_bump(data=KNA, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#0033a0", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=DUA, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#00539B", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=MSUA, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#18453B", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=KUA, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#0051ba", size = .75) +
  geom_point(data=APLong, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School, color=School), size = .5) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#00539B", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#0051BA", "#0033A0", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#18453B", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey")) +
  geom_point(data=KUA, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School, color=School), size = 1.5) +
  geom_text(data=KNA |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank, label = "KY"), color = "#0033a0", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=KNA |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "KY"), color = "#0033a0", size = 3, hjust = -.5) +
  geom_text(data=DUA |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank + 1, label = "DU"), color = "#00539B", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=DUA |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "DU"), color = "#00539B", size = 3, hjust = -.5) +
  geom_text(data=MSUA |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank + 2, label = "MSU"), color = "#18453B", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=MSUA |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .175, y=Rank, label = "MSU"), color = "#18453B", size = 3, hjust = -0.35) +
  geom_text(data=KUA |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank + 2, label = "KU"), color = "#0051ba", size = 3, hjust = 1, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_text(data=KUA |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "KU"), color = "#0051ba", size = 3, hjust = -.5, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:17) +
  theme_minimal()  +
  labs(
    x="Week", 
    y="AP"
    )

CoachesChart <- ggplot() +
  geom_bump(data=CoachesLong, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "lightgrey", size = .4) +
  geom_bump(data=KNC, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#0033a0", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=DUC, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#00539B", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=MSUC, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#18453B", size = .5) +
  geom_bump(data=KUC, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School), color = "#0051ba", size = .75) +
  geom_point(data=CoachesLong, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School, color=School), size = .5) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#00539B", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#0051BA", "#0033A0", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "#18453B", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey", "lightgrey")) +
  geom_point(data=KUC, aes(x=Week, y=Rank, group=School, color=School), size = 1.5) +
  geom_text(data=KNC |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank, label = "KY"), color = "#0033a0", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=KNC |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "KY"), color = "#0033a0", size = 3, hjust = -.5) +
  geom_text(data=DUC |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank, label = "DU"), color = "#00539B", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=DUC |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "DU"), color = "#00539B", size = 3, hjust = -.5) +
  geom_text(data=MSUC |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank, label = "MSU"), color = "#18453B", size = 3, hjust = 1) +
  geom_text(data=MSUC |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .175, y=Rank, label = "MSU"), color = "#18453B", size = 3, hjust = -0.35) +
  geom_text(data=KUC |> filter(Week == min(Week)), aes(x = Week - .2, y=Rank, label = "KU"), color = "#0051ba", size = 3, hjust = 1, fontface = "bold") +
  geom_text(data=KUC |> filter(Week == max(Week)), aes(x = Week - .1, y=Rank, label = "KU"), color = "#0051ba", size = 3, hjust = -.5, fontface = "bold") +
  scale_y_reverse() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1:17) +
   theme_minimal()  +
  labs(
    x="Rank", 
    y="Coaches"
    )

APChart / CoachesChart +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Jayhawks are a Lock",
    subtitle = "AP Poll and Coaches Poll have Kansas on top",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)
  ) + 
  theme(legend.position = "none")









The 2020 Men’s National Champion… The Kansas Jayhawks. Well that is what would have been said if Covid-19 didn’t knock out all of Lawrence’s competition. With all the numbers, polls, stats and gradings system there isn’t a whole lot saying Bill Self wouldn’t have added another ring to his collection.
With the lights set to shine on at Mercedes-Benz Stadium in Atlanta, Georgia on April 6, 2020 would the Jayhawks bring home another title, or would this have been one of the greatest “what if” teams in history? The truth is, we’ll never know, but let’s speculate and hang up a banner to remember this historic season and honor the team that brought us back to the Holy Land.

title: Did Hunter Dickinson Ruin Kansas Basketball
text:
After the 2022-2023 Men’s College Basketball Season came to a close, the biggest name in the new transfer portal wasn’t a surprise. Hunter Dickinson, the 7-foot-1 All-American center from Michigan, had two years of eligibility left and a decision that would change the landscape of college basketball forever.
Coming off an unusual early exit in the NCAA Tournament, a Round of 32 loss to Arkansas, Kansas head coach Bill Self knew he had to change something. The Jayhawks had returning talent, upcoming stars coming in, but they needed a big man to secure the paint. A player who has dominated inside on big stages and can replicate the greats who have come before him.
The Dickinson Era…
With an outrageous NIL valuation of $800,000, every major program in the country made their pitch. Kentucky, Maryland, Villanova, and Georgetown were all in the race, but Kansas had something the others didn’t. The track record of developing big men into national champions by the 17-time Big 12 Champion head coach, Bill Self.
For Self, this was more than just another roster spot, it was a statement to the rest of the nation that the Jayhawks are back. After years of relying on guard-heavy lineups, Dickinson could be the centerpiece of the offense and a game changer in the Big 12.
Allen Fieldhouse had new life from the moment the season tipped off, with a new face leading the troops. Backed by a program built on legacy, tradition, and excellence, the Jayhawks ranked No. 1 in the AP Preseason Poll. Could Dickinson be the answered prayer of Lawrence?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)
library(dplyr)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(waffle)
library(gt)

HDPerGame <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Dickenson Per Game.csv")
HDPer40M <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Dickenson Per 40 Min.csv")
HDPer100P <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Dickenson Per 100 Poss.csv")
HDadv <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Dickenson Advanced.csv")
HDtotals <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Dickenson Totals.csv")
S2020.21 <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - 2020-21 Full Team Season Stats.csv")
S2021.22 <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - 2021-22 Full Team Season Stats.csv")
S2022.23 <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - 2022-23 Full Team Season Stats.csv")
S2023.24 <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - 2023-24 Full Team Season Stats.csv")
S2024.25 <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - 2024-25 Full Team Season Stats.csv")
KU.Record.History <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - KU Record History.csv")
MU.Record.History <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - Michigan Record History.csv")
KU.MU.Record.History  <- read_csv("Project 1 Data/Project 1 Data - KU vs MU Record.csv")

KU <- KU.MU.Record.History |> filter(Team =="KU", Season != "2025-26")
MU <- KU.MU.Record.History |> filter(Team =="Michigan", Season != "2025-26")

KU24.25 <- KU |> filter(Season == "2024-25")
KU23.24 <- KU |> filter(Season == "2023-24")
MU20.21 <- MU |> filter(Season == "2020-21")
MU21.22 <- MU |> filter(Season == "2021-22")
MU22.23 <- MU |> filter(Season == "2022-23")

KUBar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=KU, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=KU24.25, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "#0051ba") +
  geom_bar(data=KU23.24, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "#0051ba") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="Kansas's Season's", 
    y="SRS Grade"
    )

MUBar <- ggplot() +
  geom_bar(data=MU, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "lightgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=MU20.21, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "#00274C") +
  geom_bar(data=MU21.22, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "#00274C") +
  geom_bar(data=MU22.23, aes(x=Season, weight=`C. Wins`), fill = "#00274C") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    x="Michigan's Season's", 
    y=" "
    )

KUBar / MUBar +
  plot_annotation(
    title = "The Biggest Transfer Bust of All Time",
    subtitle = "Kansas and Michigan saw better results against better teams without Dickinson",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 12), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=14), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=12)
  )









While Kansas’s Simple System Rating dropped, Michigan found a new life with Dickinson’s departure. With an already established resume, Hunter found ways to make an impact on the star-studded roster in Lawrence.
Transitioning from the Big 10 to the Big 12 might not seem like a massive difference, but the style and competition level tell a different story. Both conferences are known for their physicality and depth, yet Kansas and Michigan operated in very different systems. So where do these two programs stack up against the rest of the Power 4? Did Dickinson’s arrival ruin the Jayhawks’ established legacy, or did Kansas simply cool off after years of dominance?


Code
NCAAs20_21 <- S2020.21 |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2020-2021")
NCAAs21_22 <- S2021.22 |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2021-2022")
NCAAs22_23 <- S2022.23 |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2022-2023")
NCAAs23_24 <- S2023.24 |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2023-2024")
NCAAs24_25 <- S2024.25 |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2024-2025")

NCAATotalSeasons <- bind_rows(NCAAs20_21, NCAAs21_22, NCAAs22_23, NCAAs23_24, NCAAs24_25)

Big10 <- NCAATotalSeasons |> filter(School %in% c(
  "Illinois", "Indiana", "Iowa", "Maryland", "Michigan", "Michigan State",
  "Minnesota", "Nebraska", "Northwestern", "Ohio State", "Penn State",
  "Purdue", "Rutgers", "Wisconsin", "Oregon", "UCLA", "Southern California", "Washington"))

ACC <- NCAATotalSeasons |> filter(School %in% c(
  "Boston College", "Clemson", "Duke", "Florida State", "Georgia Tech",
  "Louisville", "Miami", "North Carolina", "NC State", "Notre Dame",
  "Pittsburgh", "Syracuse", "Virginia", "Virginia Tech", "Wake Forest"))

Big12 <- NCAATotalSeasons |> filter(School %in% c(
  "Baylor", "Brigham Young", "Cincinnati", "Houston", "Iowa State", "Kansas",
  "Kansas State", "Oklahoma", "Oklahoma State", "TCU", "Texas",
  "Texas Tech", "UCF", "West Virginia"))

SEC <- NCAATotalSeasons |> filter(School %in% c(
  "Alabama", "Arkansas", "Auburn", "Florida", "Georgia", "Kentucky",
  "Louisiana State", "Mississippi", "Mississippi State", "Missouri", "South Carolina",
  "Tennessee", "Texas A&M", "Vanderbilt", "Ole Miss"))

Power4 <- bind_rows(Big10, ACC, Big12, SEC)

KUs20_21 <- S2020.21 |> filter(School == "Kansas") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2020-2021")
KUs21_22 <- S2021.22 |> filter(School == "Kansas") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2021-2022")
KUs22_23 <- S2022.23 |> filter(School == "Kansas") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2022-2023")
KUs23_24 <- S2023.24 |> filter(School == "Kansas") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2023-2024")
KUs24_25 <- S2024.25 |> filter(School == "Kansas") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2024-2025")

KansasTotalSeasons <- bind_rows(KUs20_21, KUs21_22, KUs22_23, KUs23_24, KUs24_25)

MUs20_21 <- S2020.21 |> filter(School == "Michigan") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2020-2021")
MUs21_22 <- S2021.22 |> filter(School == "Michigan") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2021-2022")
MUs22_23 <- S2022.23 |> filter(School == "Michigan") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2022-2023")
MUs23_24 <- S2023.24 |> filter(School == "Michigan") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2023-2024")
MUs24_25 <- S2024.25 |> filter(School == "Michigan") |> select (School, G, `Points Scored`, `FG%`, TRB, AST) |> mutate(Season = "2024-2025")

MichiganTotalSeasons <- bind_rows(MUs20_21, MUs21_22, MUs22_23, MUs23_24, MUs24_25)

season_levels <- c("2020-2021", "2021-2022", "2022-2023", "2023-2024", "2024-2025")

Power4.2 <- Power4 |> mutate(Season = factor(Season, levels = season_levels))

KansasTotalSeasons2 <- KansasTotalSeasons |> mutate(Season = factor(Season, levels = season_levels))
MichiganTotalSeasons2 <- MichiganTotalSeasons |> mutate(Season = factor(Season, levels = season_levels))


PointBar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Power4.2, aes(x=Season, y=`Points Scored`, group=School), color="lightgrey", size=.3) +
  geom_line(data=KansasTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=`Points Scored`, group=1), color="#0051ba", size=.75) +
  geom_line(data=MichiganTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=`Points Scored`, group=1), color="#FFCB05", size=.75) +
  labs(
    x = "",
    y = "Points"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal()

FGBar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Power4.2, aes(x=Season, y=`FG%`, group=School), color="lightgrey", size=.3) +
  geom_line(data=KansasTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=`FG%`, group=1), color="#0051ba", size=.75) +
  geom_line(data=MichiganTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=`FG%`, group=1), color="#FFCB05", size=.75) +
  labs(
    x = "",
    y = "Shooting %"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal()

TRBBar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Power4.2, aes(x=Season, y=TRB, group=School), color="lightgrey", size=.3) +
  geom_line(data=KansasTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=TRB, group=1), color="#0051ba", size=.75) +
  geom_line(data=MichiganTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=TRB, group=1), color="#FFCB05", size=.75)  +
  labs(
    x = "",
    y = "Rebounds"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal()

ASTBar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=Power4.2, aes(x=Season, y=AST, group=School), color="lightgrey", size=.3) +
  geom_line(data=KansasTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=AST, group=1), color="#0051ba", size=.75) +
  geom_line(data=MichiganTotalSeasons2, aes(x=Season, y=AST, group=1), color="#FFCB05", size=.75) +
  labs(
    x = "",
    y = "Assists"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal()

PointBar + FGBar + TRBBar + ASTBar + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "After Dickinson, Michigan Got Better",
    subtitle = "After the 5 Star Center Transferred to the Jayhawks, the Wolverines found Success",
    caption = "Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(size=7.5)
  )









Seeing that both programs ranked among the top of all major programs, was Dickinson really that bad for the Jayhawks? Although neither led the nation statistically, both Kansas and Michigan found ways to return to the NCAA tournament and put together statistically solid seasons.
Looking across the Power Four, Kansas ranked near the top of total assists, a reflection of Self’s disciplined offensive system. Their points and rebounds per game stayed consistent with other powerhouse programs, but their true shooting percentage stood out among the best. Meanwhile, Michigan, after losing Dickinson, remained competitive, finishing in the upper half of all of these categories.
So what was the real reason behind the $800,000 transfer? Was Hunter Dickinson the problem, or was it simply the roster Bill Self built around him?


Code
HDPerGame |> 
  slice(1:5) |> 
  select(Season, Class, Team, MP, PTS, `FG%`,`2P%`, `3P%`, `eFG%`, TRB) |> 
  gt() |> 
  data_color(
    columns = vars(MP, `eFG%`,`FG%`),
    colors = scales::col_numeric(
      palette = c(
        "yellow", "orange", "red"),
      domain = NULL)
  ) |> 
  data_color(
    columns = vars(MP, TRB),
    colors = scales::col_numeric(
      palette = c(
        "#1E3A8A", "#3B82F6", "#93C5FD"),
      domain = NULL)
  ) |> 
    tab_header(
    title = "Dickinson's role changed after after suiting up for the Jayhawks",
    subtitle = "Kansas's Top Transfer of 2023, saw his numbers decline after leaving Michigan "
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", weight = "bold", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("title")
  ) |> tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "black", align = "left", size=18),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
  ) |>
  tab_source_note(
    source_note = md("**Source: Sports Reference | By Camden Otto")
  ) |>
  tab_style(
     locations = cells_column_labels(columns = everything()),
     style = list(
       cell_borders(sides = "bottom", weight = px(3)),
       cell_text(weight = "bold", size=15)
     ))

With the 7-footers’ overall shooting percentages decreasing, he found other ways to make an impact on this roster while rebounding and finding other stars on his team. With a heavy load for the 5-star transfer to fill and a lot of hype built on short success, was Lawrence the best home for Dickinson?
In the end, Hunter Dickinson’s time at Kansas will be remembered as a mix of promise and what could have been. He brought leadership, experience, and attention back to the post, qualities any program would value, but the results didn’t quite match the hype. The Jayhawks have been competitive but have not reached their full potential since their historic 2022 championship.
This comes to ask, did Dickinson really ruin Kansas basketball, or was Bill Self just another coach navigating the challenges of the transfer portal? For the upcoming season, Bill Self invested in both top freshmen and transfers, rounding out a roster valued at nearly $10 million. But is bringing in fifth-year seniors truly worth the cost and time, or would it be more beneficial to focus on developing young freshmen with untapped potential?
